Angered by Democratic success in the recent budget deal, Republicans aim for policy wins in year-end spending package.
We're working on more stories right now

                                            By 
                                                    Issac J. Bailey


                                            By 
                                                    David Makovsky


                                            By 
                                                    Barney Frank


                                            By 
Benjamin Wofford


                AP Photo

            By 
Seung Min Kim

11/05/15 01:30 PM EST
After months of blocking spending bills, Senate Democrats are finally letting one government appropriations measure come to the floor. 
Just hours after filibustering the spending bill that funds the Pentagon, Democrats plan to relent and allow a separate funding measure that pays for military construction and veterans programs to advance on the Senate floor on Thursday. 
Story Continued Below
The rationale for Democrats easing their blockade on that legislation, known on the Hill as Milcon-VA, is that it’s a relatively smaller funding bill that’s more equally split between domestic and defense spending — rather than the Pentagon measure, which is all defense spending. Democrats had filibustered spending bills all year in order to pressure Republicans into a broader budget deal that would increase both domestic and military spending.
“If senators cooperate in moving things along and scheduling votes on amendments to the bill, we can vote on passage on Tuesday night so that senators can commemorate Veterans Day back home with their constituents,” Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) said Thursday as he teed up the vote. “Obviously this is going to require some cooperation from all members.”
If the Milcon-VA bill advances as expected on Thursday afternoon, it could also be used as the vehicle for the broader omnibus spending bill that covers funding for all government agencies. Congress needs to approve a new spending law before Dec. 11 to avoid a government shutdown. But with a broader budget deal already in place, which raised spending limits overall, both parties hope to resolve their differences over lower-tier policy issues and avoid a shutdown in a few weeks. 
“I’m pleased the Republican leader appears to have come around and decided now to move forward on one of our nondefense priorities: the funding of veterans programs,” Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) said Thursday. “I’m hopeful that the Milcon-VA appropriations bill will help us move towards a bipartisan omnibus funding bill both parties can accept.”
Earlier Thursday, Senate Democrats blocked the appropriations measure funding for the Defense Department on a 51-44 vote. 
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
title: Dems ease spending bill blockade
